text: When the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission released their final forensic report on the causes of the 2008 financial collapse on Wall Street – the worst collapse since the 1929-1932 collapse – it pointed to hidden leverage in off-balance sheet entities at the megabanks on Wall Street as a key driver of the crisis. It wrote: “From 2000 to 2007, large banks and thrifts generally had $16 to $22 in assets for each dollar of capital, for leverage ratios between 16:1 and 22:1. For some banks, leverage remained roughly constant. JP Morgan’s reported leverage was between 20:1 and 22:1. Wells Fargo’s generally ranged between 16:1 and 17:1. Other banks upped their leverage. Bank of America’s rose from 18:1 in 2000 to 27:1 in 2007. Citigroup’s increased from 18:1 to 22:1, then shot up to 32:1 by the end of 2007, when Citi brought off-balance sheet assets onto the balance sheet. More than other banks, Citigroup held assets off of its balance sheet, in part to hold down capital requirements. In 2007, even after bringing $80 billion worth of assets on balance sheet, substantial assets remained off. If those had been included, leverage in 2007 would have been 48:1, or about 53% higher. In comparison, at Wells Fargo and Bank of America, including off-balance-sheet assets would have raised the 2007 leverage ratios 17% and 28%, respectively

text: Mastering AI and Machine Learning with Clean and Accurate Data - https://lnkd.in/gFcN2_2D In today's data-driven landscape, artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) are at the forefront of business innovation. However, the real value of these technologies is deeply tied to the quality of the data they rely on. Clean and accurate data is the foundation for building effective AI models that can deliver reliable insights and decision-making power.  Why Data Quality Matters AI and ML algorithms are only as good as the data they are fed. Poor-quality data can lead to flawed models that produce inaccurate or biased predictions. Clean, well-structured, and accurate data ensures that these models are trained properly, providing the clarity needed for businesses to make strategic decisions.  Common Data Quality Issues -  Incomplete data : Missing values can skew model predictions. -  Duplicate records : These can inflate patterns and distort trends. -  Inconsistent formatting : Differing date formats, units of measurement, or categorizations can lead to incorrect interpretations. -  Outliers and anomalies : Extreme values can throw off model accuracy, leading to overfitting.  The Path to Clean Data To master AI and ML, companies must implement strong data cleaning and preprocessing practices: -  Data cleansing : Removing inconsistencies, fixing errors, and filling in gaps. -  Normalization and standardization : Ensuring data is uniform and usable across systems. -  Feature engineering : Enhancing the predictive power of data by creating new variables that capture underlying patterns.  Data Governance and Validation Ensuring data quality isn’t just a one-time effort. Continuous  data governance  and  validation  processes are critical for maintaining high standards. By using tools like  Pandas ,  Trifacta , or  Alteryx , organizations can streamline the data cleaning process, making data preparation faster and more accurate.  The Impact of Clean Data on AI Success In industries like healthcare, finance, and retail, high-quality data allows AI models to detect fraud, predict customer behavior, and personalize services more effectively. For instance, a financial services firm using clean transactional data was able to boost the accuracy of their fraud detection model by 35%—a direct testament to the power of accurate data.  Conclusion For businesses to truly unlock the potential of AI and ML, clean and accurate data is non-negotiable. As AI technologies advance, the emphasis on data quality will only grow. By focusing on high-quality data, organizations can ensure their AI initiatives drive real value and provide actionable insights for the future.

name: Stephen J. Scott
text: Don't miss this week's "Weekend Reading" article! Herein, I continue from last week's post with Part 2 on the ongoing confusion between governance and culture, and offer a new framework for culture risk governance.  When seeking to demonstrate that they have achieved an effective non-financial risk management posture, bank risk leaders typically point to alignment between their internal policies and regulatory expectations. They then highlight their related processes, operated through robust governance structures and systems of control.  But between policies and processes (let’s call them ‘governance inputs’), and the costly outcomes that are later seen (‘performance outputs’), much poorly understood activity takes place (‘operational throughputs’). These operational throughputs are as essential to the success of risk governance as are the more immediately tangible policies and processes, but because this activity is less formalized, it is less well recognized.  To truly manage non-financial risk, we must understand:  -People: The informal networks through which work actually happens -Presumptions: The often conflicting presumptions that guide executive decision-making -Practices: The real practices that emerge, sometimes contrary to stated policies  Incorporating these elements alongside governance inputs and performance outputs completes the diagnostic framework and represents a fundamentally different way of approaching risk. Executives looking to improve their organization's culture risk governance capabilities would do well to take note.

text: When the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission released their final forensic report on the causes of the 2008 financial collapse on Wall Street – the worst collapse since the 1929-1932 collapse – it pointed to hidden leverage in off-balance sheet entities at the megabanks on Wall Street as a key driver of the crisis. It wrote: “From 2000 to 2007, large banks and thrifts generally had $16 to $22 in assets for each dollar of capital, for leverage ratios between 16:1 and 22:1. For some banks, leverage remained roughly constant. JP Morgan’s reported leverage was between 20:1 and 22:1. Wells Fargo’s generally ranged between 16:1 and 17:1. Other banks upped their leverage. Bank of America’s rose from 18:1 in 2000 to 27:1 in 2007. Citigroup’s increased from 18:1 to 22:1, then shot up to 32:1 by the end of 2007, when Citi brought off-balance sheet assets onto the balance sheet. More than other banks, Citigroup held assets off of its balance sheet, in part to hold down capital requirements. In 2007, even after bringing $80 billion worth of assets on balance sheet, substantial assets remained off. If those had been included, leverage in 2007 would have been 48:1, or about 53% higher. In comparison, at Wells Fargo and Bank of America, including off-balance-sheet assets would have raised the 2007 leverage ratios 17% and 28%, respectively

name: Stephen J. Scott
text: Don't miss this week's "Weekend Reading" article! Herein, I continue from last week's post with Part 2 on the ongoing confusion between governance and culture, and offer a new framework for culture risk governance.  When seeking to demonstrate that they have achieved an effective non-financial risk management posture, bank risk leaders typically point to alignment between their internal policies and regulatory expectations. They then highlight their related processes, operated through robust governance structures and systems of control.  But between policies and processes (let’s call them ‘governance inputs’), and the costly outcomes that are later seen (‘performance outputs’), much poorly understood activity takes place (‘operational throughputs’). These operational throughputs are as essential to the success of risk governance as are the more immediately tangible policies and processes, but because this activity is less formalized, it is less well recognized.  To truly manage non-financial risk, we must understand:  -People: The informal networks through which work actually happens -Presumptions: The often conflicting presumptions that guide executive decision-making -Practices: The real practices that emerge, sometimes contrary to stated policies  Incorporating these elements alongside governance inputs and performance outputs completes the diagnostic framework and represents a fundamentally different way of approaching risk. Executives looking to improve their organization's culture risk governance capabilities would do well to take note.
